The "Sickle Cell Disease Research, Surveillance, Prevention, and Treatment Act of 2014" establishes a program for research, surveillance, prevention, and treatment of sickle cell disease. It authorizes the Secretary to conduct or support research to find a cure for the disease. The "Sickle Cell Disease Research, Surveillance, Prevention, and Treatment Act of 2014" includes a section on sickle cell disease surveillance. Section 399V-6 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include grants for surveillance and data maintenance on sickle cell disease in up to 20 States. This includes public health initiatives to improve access to quality healthcare for sickle cell disease. The amended Public Health Service Act includes grants for surveillance and data maintenance on sickle cell disease in up to 20 States, focusing on improving access to quality healthcare for sickle cell disease. This involves disease-related health care, proven treatments like Hydroxyurea, promoting guidelines for screening, prevention, and treatment, supporting community-based organizations and health departments in education and training activities, and training State health providers. The amended Public Health Service Act includes grants for surveillance and data maintenance on sickle cell disease in up to 20 States, focusing on improving access to quality healthcare for sickle cell disease. This involves supporting and training State health departments and regional laboratories in comprehensive testing to identify specific forms of sickle cell disease in people of all ages, as well as identifying and evaluating promising strategies for prevention and treatment of sickle cell disease complications. The Secretary will award grants to States for surveillance and data collection on sickle cell disease, focusing on therapies, prevention strategies, and risk factors affecting health outcomes. Grants aim to include data on the majority of the US sickle cell disease population. States must submit applications to seek grants. The Secretary may require time, manner, and information for surveillance and data collection on sickle cell disease. COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY-BASED ENTITIES: Entities seeking grants must collaborate with community-based organizations experienced in serving sickle cell disease patients.

SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS: $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal years 2015 through 2020 to support the provisions outlined in the Public Health Service Act.
